stimulus:
In this study, you will read text scenarios and make slider judgments about the situations which they describe. Here is an image of an example trial.


In the upcoming trials, please read the description and give your answer by clicking on the slider. We are interested in your intuitive judgment, so no need to second-guess yourself.

You must make a slider judgment in each trial. You will not receive any feedback.


When you are ready to begin, press the start button.

Emma's friend, Sarah, needs to cancel their dinner plans because she has a work emergency.
Sarah: "I'm really sorry, but I have to stay late at work tonight. I won't be able to make it to dinner."
Emma: "That's understandable. Work comes first. We can always reschedule."

How understandable does Emma think Sarah's reasons are?

After a trip to an art museum, Emily talks about her favorite exhibits with David.
Emily: "The contemporary art section was fascinating! I could spend hours there!"
David: "I actually thought it was a bit boring. I didn't really understand the art."

How boring were the exhibits for David?

Claire is studying for an exam, but her younger siblings are playing noisily in the next room.
Claire: "It's difficult to study with all the noise. Can you please be a bit quieter?"

How difficult is it for Claire to study?

Ben's cousin Amy asks him if he's coming to their monthly family gathering.
Amy: "Are you coming to the family dinner this evening?"
Ben: "I'd love to, but I'm exhausted from work this week. I'll catch up with everyone next time."

How tired is Ben?

David observes that his colleague has been distant.
David: "I've noticed you haven't been as chatty as usual, and am a bit concerned. Is everything okay at home?"

How concerned is David?
